In the early 1920s, radio broadcasting started consolidating, with Radio Corporation of America (RCA) acquiring WEAF from AT&T and merging it with Westinghouse's WJZ to form the National Broadcasting Company (NBC) in 1926. NBC was divided into the Red and Blue Networks, focusing on commercial and non-commercial programming, respectively. In 1927, NBC expanded to the West Coast with the Orange and Gold Networks. After General Electric divested from RCA in 1930, NBC moved to the Rockefeller Center in 1933. The iconic three-note NBC chimes were introduced in 1931.

In the late 1930s, the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) investigated network broadcasting monopolies, leading to RCA selling NBC Blue to Edward J. Noble in 1943, who renamed it the American Broadcasting Company (ABC) in 1945. NBC hosted many popular performers and programs, including Bing Crosby, Al Jolson, Jack Benny, and Arturo Toscanini's NBC Symphony Orchestra.

In 1943, RCA sold NBC Blue to Edward J. Noble, who renamed it the American Broadcasting Company (ABC). The sale included the Blue Network name, leases on landlines, New York studios, two-and-a-half radio stations, contracts with actors, and agreements with around 60 affiliates. To comply with FCC radio station ownership limits, Noble sold off his existing New York City radio station WMCA. Noble acquired the "American Broadcasting Company" name from George B. Storer in 1944. The Blue Network became ABC officially on June 15, 1945. NBC hosted many popular performers and programs, including Bing Crosby, Al Jolson, Jack Benny, and Arturo Toscanini's NBC Symphony Orchestra. However, in the late 1940s, rival CBS gained ground by allowing radio stars to use their own production companies to produce programs, leading to many NBC performers, including Jack Benny, jumping to CBS. NBC stars also began migrating to television, causing a decline in NBC's radio programming. In 1975, NBC launched the NBC News and Information Service (NIS), which provided up to 55 minutes of news per hour around the clock to local stations. However, it was discontinued in 1977 due to financial reasons. In 1979, NBC launched The Source, a secondary network providing news and short features to FM rock stations. The NBC Radio Network was sold to Westwood One in 1987, which continued to feature "NBC"-branded programming until 2003, when NBC News Radio was launched, anchored by NBC and MSNBC talent. In 2011, Westwood One was merged into Dial Global, taking that syndicator's name.

In 1943, RCA sold NBC Blue to Edward J. Noble, who renamed it ABC. The Blue Network became ABC officially on June 15, 1945. NBC, previously known for popular programs and performers, began to decline in the late 1940s due to competition from CBS and the rise of television. In 1975, NBC launched the NBC News and Information Service (NIS), which was discontinued in 1977. In 1979, NBC launched The Source, a secondary network providing news and short features to FM rock stations. In 1992, Mutual and NBC newscasts were jointly produced in overnights and weekends, and both networks aired generic sportscasts through the weekend. Westwood One purchased Unistar Radio Networks from Infinity Broadcasting in 1994, and Infinity acquired 25 percent of Westwood One, becoming its largest shareholder and assuming control. Infinity was then acquired by Westinghouse Electric Corporation for $5 billion in 1996, with the CBS Radio Network also falling under Westwood One management. The Mutual/NBC newsroom in Arlington closed in 1998, and "NBC"-branded newscasts produced by CBS were restricted to morning drive (ET) on weekdays. Westwood One launched NBC News Radio on March 31, 2003, anchored by NBC and MSNBC talent, but limited to one-minute newscasts on weekdays. Dial Global ended distribution of CNN Radio newscasts and made NBC News Radio a full-time operation in April 2012. NBC Sports Radio was launched in 2013 as a Dial Global/NBC Sports joint venture, but ended 24/7 programming in 2018 and was shut down in 2020. Cumulus Media acquired Dial Global in 2013, which reverted to the Westwood One name and was merged into Cumulus Media Networks. NBC News Radio ended operations on December 15, 2014. In 1944, NBC began regularly scheduling television programs, including The Voice of Firestone Televues and The War As It Happens, which was the first news cast regularly seen in multiple cities. NBC's coverage of V-E Day and the 1947 World Series contributed to the growth of television. Under the leadership of Sylvester "Pat" Weaver in the late 1940s and early 1950s, NBC launched successful shows such as Today, The Tonight Show, and Wide Wide World. NBC also commissioned the first opera written for television, Amahl and the Night Visitors, in 1951. In the mid-1950s, NBC began broadcasting in color and aired the first live color production of Peter Pan in 1955. NBC also acquired the rights to Walt Disney's anthology series in 1961 and began airing it in color. By 1965, NBC was broadcasting 95% of its prime time schedule in color and began billing itself as "The Full Color Network." In the late 1960s, the networks, including NBC, moved to clean house of veteran shows to attract the large youth population. NBC acquired the broadcast rights to The Wizard of Oz in 1967, which it aired annually until 1976 when CBS re-acquired the rights.

In the late 1960s, NBC acquired the rights to broadcast The Wizard of Oz, which had been a long-time staple on CBS. The network aimed to attract younger viewers by canceling older shows and acquiring broadcast rights to popular films and producing costly movies, miniseries, and specials. However, these efforts failed to draw the desired 18-34 demographic and alienated older viewers. In the 1970s, NBC entered a slump, with many of its new shows failing to attract viewers. The network's lone success was the groundbreaking late-night comedy/variety show, Saturday Night Live. During this time, several longtime NBC affiliates defected to other networks, such as ABC and CBS, due to NBC's poor performance. The network's future was further placed in doubt when President Jimmy Carter pulled the U.S. team out of the 1980 Summer Olympics, causing NBC to cancel its planned 150 hours of coverage. The network's struggles were met with criticism from both the press and within the company, with a parody song titled "Loud as a Peacock" blaming NBC's problems on then-president Fred Silverman.

In the late 1960s, NBC tried to attract younger viewers by acquiring popular films and producing costly content, but failed and entered a slump in the 1970s. The network's struggles, including the cancellation of 1980 Summer Olympics coverage, led to criticism and the parody song "Loud as a Peacock." Fred Silverman resigned as president and Grant Tinker and Brandon Tartikoff took over. Tartikoff focused on promising programs, such as Hill Street Blues and Cheers, and moved them to better time slots. The network's fortunes began to turn with shows like The A-Team and Late Night with David Letterman. In 1984, The Cosby Show's success led to a resurgence in sitcoms and NBC's rise in the ratings. The network also increased in-house productions and launched a syndication package for its owned-and-operated stations. By 1988, NBC had 17 series in Nielsen's Top 30 and ranked first in the weekly ratings for over a year.

In the late 1980s, NBC increased its in-house productions and launched a syndication package, leading to a successful run of shows like The Cosby Show. However, some syndicated game shows, such as Wheel of Fortune and Jeopardy!, outrated NBC's shows in many markets. Despite the cancellation of some shows, NBC's fortunes improved with hits like The A-Team and Late Night with David Letterman. The network's success continued into the 1990s with shows like The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air, Blossom, and Law & Order. The "Must See TV" brand was introduced for NBC's strong Thursday night lineup, particularly the comedies. The network also acquired Telemundo and Vivendi Universal Entertainment in the early 2000s. However, NBC lost the broadcast rights to Major League Baseball, the NBA, and later, the National Hockey League. Despite these losses, NBC retained the rights to the Olympics, PGA Tour golf events, and Notre Dame football.

NBC reclaimed the top spot in ratings from 1999 to 2002, but lost broadcast rights to Major League Baseball and the NBA. The network then acquired Telemundo and Vivendi Universal Entertainment, forming NBC Universal. However, NBC's ratings fell to fourth place in the early 2000s due to increased competition from cable, home video, video games, and the internet. Despite this, NBC found success with its summer schedule, particularly with America's Got Talent. In 2009, Comcast announced it would purchase a controlling stake in NBC Universal from General Electric. NBC's broadcast of the 2010 Winter Olympics saw a ratings increase, but the network lost $250 million in advertising revenue. The 2009-2010 season ended with only a few shows being renewed for second seasons, while others were cancelled. NBC's decision to air The Jay Leno Show in prime time received criticism and had little impact on the network's ratings. The network's ratings increased in the 2010-2011 season due to the success of NBC Sunday Night Football. In 2010, Comcast announced it would acquire a majority interest in NBC Universal, and Jeff Zucker stepped down as CEO once the merger was completed.

NBC, in an attempt to revive its falling ratings, decided to air The Jay Leno Show daily in prime time in 2009, causing criticism from industry executives and affiliates. The decision had little impact on ratings and was eventually moved to a later timeslot. NBC's ratings improved in the 2010-11 season due to the success of NBC Sunday Night Football, but the network still struggled to find hit shows. The network underwent a change in leadership and ownership in 2010, with Comcast acquiring a majority stake in NBC Universal. NBC's broadcast of the 2010 Winter Olympics saw a ratings increase but a loss in advertising revenue. The network's ratings were mostly boosted by its successful shows such as The Voice, Sunday Night Football, and Chicago Fire, leading NBC to become the No. 1 network in the 18-49 demographic in the 2013-14 season for the first time since 2003-04. However, the network's success was mixed in the following seasons, with some new shows failing to gain traction and others, like The Blacklist, experiencing a decline in viewership. NBC's dominance in the 2010s faded during the 2019-20 season due to the COVID-19 pandemic, causing a major disruption in the network's programming.
